Bird flu in milk is alarming — but not for the reason you thinkKenny Torrella4/25/2024

The US Department of Agriculture’s failed response to bird flu in cows, explained.

flu has had a busy couple of years. 
Since 2022, it’s ravaged the US poultry industry, as more than 90 million farmed birds — mostly egg-laying hens and turkeys — have either died from the virus or have been brutally killed in an attempt to stop the spread.
Last month, confirmation that the virus — a strain of highly pathogenic avian influenza known as H5N1 — had infected US dairy cows alarmed infectious disease experts, who worry that transmission to cows will allow the virus more opportunities to evolve. One dairy worker fell ill, increasing concerns about human risk levels. 
---
How did bird flu get so bad? Vox offers clarity.
We’ve been in the US’s worst bird flu outbreak since 2022. It continues to circulate on poultry farms, in wildlife, and now dairy farms. Here’s what you need to know:
* Yes, bird flu is a threat. It’s time to take it seriously.
* Bird flu jumped to cows, then to a human. Should we be worried?
* Can you get bird flu?
* Bird flu is surging again on poultry farms. The US is normalizing the cruelest mass killing method to stop it.
---
Now it’s in the milk supply. On Tuesday, the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) confirmed that genetic evidence of the virus had been found in commercially purchased milk. However, it’s unclear whether the milk contains live virus or mere fragments of the virus that were killed by pasteurization, a process that destroys harmful bacteria, but remain detectable. 
The FDA said it’ll soon release a nationwide survey of tested milk and that for now, the commercial milk supply remains safe, a claim that numerous independent experts have confirmed.
The news that the bird flu has been found in the US milk supply may raise alarm among some consumers, and the FDA has been criticized for prematurely assuring the safety of milk without hard data. But the real problem, which has received little attention, is the tepid and opaque response from the federal agency tasked with stopping the on-farm spread of the disease: the US Department of Agriculture (USDA).
What we know — and what we don’t — depends on the USDA 
Ever since the virus was detected on a Texas dairy farm in late March, infectious disease experts around the world have roundly criticized the USDA on multiple fronts. 
It took nearly a month for the agency to upload data containing genetic sequences of the virus, which scientists use to better understand its threat level. And once the sequence was uploaded, it was incomplete, lacking specifics that researchers say they needed to properly study the data.
“It’s as if the USDA is intentionally trying to hide data from the world,” Rick Bright, a former director of the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority at the US Department of Health and Human Services, told STAT. A Dutch virologist told STAT it should’ve taken the USDA days, not weeks, to share data and updates. 
Beyond the data obfuscation, there’s insufficient monitoring. The virus may have started circulating on US dairy farms months before it was detected, according to Michael Worobey, a biology professor at the University of Arizona. That suggests the need for better and more proactive pathogen monitoring on the part of the USDA.
And once H5N1 was confirmed in dairy cows, the USDA didn’t require dairy farms to conduct routine testing nor report positive H5N1 tests. The USDA has even tolerated uncooperative farmers, despite the high stakes of the disease spread.
“There has been a little bit of reluctance for some of the producers to allow us to gather information from their farms,” said Michael Watson, administrator of USDA’s Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, in a press conference on Wednesday. But, he added, “that has been improving.” 
This voluntary approach is a recurring theme in USDA policy; there’s even uncertainty as to whether the agency is enforcing orders for farmers to toss milk from infected cows to ensure it doesn’t wind up in the food supply, which could explain how traces of it were found in store-bought milk. 
Last week, the New York Times reported that North Carolina officials confirmed there were asymptomatic cows in the state, which could also explain why the virus was detected in the commercial milk supply. It also suggests more herds may be infected than previously thought.
On Wednesday, a month after the first confirmation, the USDA finally issued a federal order requiring that laboratories and state veterinarians report farms with positive H5N1 tests and that lactating dairy cows must test negative for bird flu before crossing state lines (and cooperate with investigators). At a Wednesday press conference, the agency didn’t specify how the order will be enforced.
Why regulation and response go hand-in-hand
The USDA’s sluggish response to a rapidly moving virus may leave some foreign observers scratching their heads. But much of it can be explained by an irresolvable conflict baked into its mission.
The agency, according to food industry scholars Gabriel Rosenberg and Jan Dutkiewicz, has “the oxymoronic double mandate of both promoting and regulating all of American agriculture—two disparate tasks that, when combined, effectively put the fox in charge of the henhouse.”
More often than not, it’s heavy on the promotion and light on the regulation.
The paradox has been at the center of its response to the bird flu’s decimation of the US poultry industry in recent years. While the USDA is developing several bird flu vaccines, it’s long been stubbornly opposed to a broad vaccination campaign due to industry fears that it’ll disrupt trade, a major source of revenue for US poultry companies, despite pleas from experts to give birds a bird flu shot. 
USDA has also been deferential to industry on matters of pollution, labor, political corruption, false advertising, and animal cruelty across numerous sectors. And it’s not the only agency that too often takes a hands-off approach to problems stemming from food production. 
The FDA has failed to stringently regulate antibiotics used in animal farming, a pressing public health threat that, in recent years, some European regulators have addressed in earnest. Agriculture is a top source of US water and air pollution, due in large part to congressional loopholes and weak enforcement on the part of the US Environmental Protection Agency.
It all adds up to what food industry experts call “agricultural exceptionalism,” in which the food industry operates under a different set of regulations than the rest of the economy. The justification of such exceptionalism is that it’s necessary, given the importance of an abundant food supply. But that’s all the more reason not to give farmers and ranchers carte blanche to let disease circulate on American farms class="_1jvzqea1 _1jvzqea0"><div class="_1j8rw6n0 _1j8rw6n1"><div class="_1j8rw6n2"><img alt="Kenny Torrella" data-chromatic="ignore" loading="lazy" width="36" height="36" decoding="async" data-nimg="1" class="_1j8rw6n3" style="color:transparent" srcSet="https://platform.vox.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/author_profile_images/195969/Torrella_Headshot.0.png?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0%2C0%2C100%2C100&w=48 1x, https://platform.vox.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/author_profile_images/195969/Torrella_Headshot.0.png?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0%2C0%2C100%2C100&w=96 2x" src="https://platform.vox.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/author_profile_images/195969/Torrella_Headshot.0.png?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0%2C0%2C100%2C100&w=96"/></div><div class="_1j8rw6n4"><a class="_1j8rw6n5" href="/authors/kenny-torrella">Kenny Torrella</a> <span class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup _1j8rw6n6">is a senior reporter for Vox’s Future Perfect section, with a focus on animal welfare and the future of meat.</span></div></div></div></div></div><div id="zephr-anchor" class="_1agbrix11"><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1agbrixk lg8ac51 lg8ac50 xkp0cg1">Bird flu has had a busy couple of years. </p></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1agbrixk lg8ac51 lg8ac50 xkp0cg1">Since 2022, it’s ravaged the US poultry industry, as more than <a href="https://www.aphis.usda.gov/livestock-poultry-disease/avian/avian-influenza/hpai-detections/commercial-backyard-flocks">90 million</a> farmed birds — mostly egg-laying hens and turkeys — have either died from the virus or have been <a href="/future-perfect/23963820/bird-flu-surge-us-ventilation-shutdown-veterinarians">brutally killed</a> in an attempt to stop the spread.</p></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1agbrixk lg8ac51 lg8ac50 xkp0cg1">Last month, confirmation that the virus — a strain of highly pathogenic avian influenza known as H5N1 — had <a href="https://www.aphis.usda.gov/news/agency-announcements/federal-state-veterinary-public-health-agencies-share-update-hpai">infected US dairy cows</a> alarmed <a href="/infectious-disease">infectious disease</a> experts, who worry that transmission to cows will allow the virus more opportunities to evolve. One dairy worker fell ill, increasing <a href="/health/24118152/explain-it-to-me-bird-flu-human-case-texas-chickens-cows-animal-agriculture">concerns</a> about human risk levels. </p></div><div class="duet--article--block-placement _80slsf1 _80slsf0 duet--article--article-body-component"><div class="duet--article--highlight _1agbrixl _1lbxzst0"><div class="_1lbxzst1"></div><div><div id="how-did-bird-flu-get-so-bad-vox-offers-clarity" class="_7ka5u1 _7ka5u0 _1lbxzst2 duet--article--standard-heading xkp0cg1"><h2 class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup">How did bird flu get so bad? Vox offers clarity.</h2></div></div><div class="_1lbxzst3"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1agbrixk lg8ac51 lg8ac50 xkp0cg1">We’ve been in the US’s worst bird flu outbreak since 2022. It continues to circulate on poultry farms, in wildlife, and now dairy farms. Here’s what you need to know:</p></div><div class="_1lbxzst5"><ul class="duet--article--unordered-list _1agbrixk _739u100 xkp0cg1 _1lbxzst6"><li class="_739u101"><span class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup"><a href="/science/23793697/bird-flu-avian-influenza-explained-pandemic-potential-wildlife">Yes, bird flu is a threat. It’s time to take it seriously.</a></span></li><li class="_739u101"><span class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup"><a href="/health/24118152/explain-it-to-me-bird-flu-human-case-texas-chickens-cows-animal-agriculture">Bird flu jumped to cows, then to a human. Should we be worried?</a></span></li><li class="_739u101"><span class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup"><a href="/science-and-health/23572561/bird-avian-flu-influenza-h5n1-pandemic-eggs">Can you get bird flu?</a></span></li><li class="_739u101"><span class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup"><a href="/future-perfect/23963820/bird-flu-surge-us-ventilation-shutdown-veterinarians">Bird flu is surging again on poultry farms. The US is normalizing the cruelest mass killing method to stop it.</a></span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1agbrixk lg8ac51 lg8ac50 xkp0cg1">Now it’s in the milk supply. On Tuesday, the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) <a href="https://www.statnews.com/2024/04/23/h5n1-bird-flu-virus-particles-in-pasteurized-milk-fda/">confirmed</a> that genetic evidence of the virus had been found in commercially purchased milk. However, it’s unclear whether the milk contains live virus or mere fragments of the virus that were killed by pasteurization, a process that destroys harmful bacteria, but remain detectable. </p></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1agbrixk lg8ac51 lg8ac50 xkp0cg1">The FDA said it’ll soon release a nationwide survey of tested milk and that for now, the commercial milk supply remains safe, a claim that <a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/bird-flu-virus-found-pasteurized-milk-though-officials-maintain-supply-rcna149084">numerous</a> independent <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2024/04/23/health/bird-flu-milk.html">experts</a> have confirmed.</p></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1agbrixk lg8ac51 lg8ac50 xkp0cg1">The news that the bird flu has been found in the US milk supply may raise alarm among some consumers, and the FDA has been <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2024/04/19/health/bird-flu-usda-cattle.html">criticized</a> for prematurely assuring the safety of milk without hard data. But the real problem, which has received little attention, is the tepid and opaque response from the federal agency tasked with stopping the on-farm spread of the disease: the US Department of Agriculture (USDA).</p></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><div id="what-we-know-and-what-we-dont-depends-on-the-usda" class="_7ka5u1 _7ka5u0 duet--article--standard-heading xkp0cg1"><h2 class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup">What we know — and what we don’t — depends on the USDA </h2></div></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1agbrixk lg8ac51 lg8ac50 xkp0cg1">Ever since the virus was detected on a Texas dairy farm in late March, infectious disease experts around the world have roundly criticized the USDA on multiple fronts. </p></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1agbrixk lg8ac51 lg8ac50 xkp0cg1">It took <a href="https://www.statnews.com/2024/04/21/usda-releases-h5n1-bird-flu-genetic-data-eagerly-awaited-by-scientists/">nearly a month</a> for the agency to upload data containing genetic sequences of the virus, which scientists use to better understand its threat level. And once the sequence was uploaded, it was incomplete, lacking specifics that researchers say they needed to properly study the data.</p></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1agbrixk lg8ac51 lg8ac50 xkp0cg1">“It’s as if the USDA is intentionally trying to hide data from the world,” Rick Bright, a former director of the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority at the US Department of Health and Human Services, <a href="https://www.statnews.com/2024/04/21/usda-releases-h5n1-bird-flu-genetic-data-eagerly-awaited-by-scientists/">told</a> STAT. A Dutch virologist <a href="https://www.statnews.com/2024/04/18/h5n1-bird-flu-scientists-want-usda-genetic-data-faster/">told</a> STAT it should’ve taken the USDA days, not weeks, to share data and updates. </p></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1agbrixk lg8ac51 lg8ac50 xkp0cg1">Beyond the data obfuscation, there’s insufficient monitoring. The virus may have started circulating on US dairy farms months before it was detected, <a href="https://www.telegraph.co.uk/global-health/science-and-disease/bird-flu-likely-spreading-in-us-cattle-since-last-year/">according</a> to Michael Worobey, a biology professor at the University of Arizona. That suggests the need for better and more proactive pathogen monitoring on the part of the USDA.</p></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1agbrixk lg8ac51 lg8ac50 xkp0cg1">And once H5N1 was confirmed in dairy cows, the USDA <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2024/04/25/bird-flu-cows-government-response/">didn’t require</a> dairy farms to conduct routine testing nor <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2024/04/24/health/tracking-bird-flu-dairy-cows/index.html#:~:text=The%20USDA%20had%20previously%20required,the%20current%20outbreak%20in%20cattle.">report positive H5N1 tests</a>. The USDA has even tolerated uncooperative farmers, despite the high stakes of the disease spread.</p></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1agbrixk lg8ac51 lg8ac50 xkp0cg1">“There has been a little bit of reluctance for some of the producers to allow us to gather information from their farms,” said Michael Watson, administrator of USDA’s Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, in a press conference on Wednesday. But, he added, “that has been improving.” </p></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1agbrixk lg8ac51 lg8ac50 xkp0cg1">This voluntary approach is a recurring theme in USDA policy; there’s even <a href="https://www.statnews.com/2024/04/24/h5n1-bird-flu-usda-orders-dairy-cow-testing/">uncertainty</a> as to whether the agency is enforcing orders for farmers to toss milk from infected cows to ensure it doesn’t wind up in the food supply, which could explain how traces of it were found in store-bought milk. </p></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1agbrixk lg8ac51 lg8ac50 xkp0cg1">Last week, the New York Times <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2024/04/19/health/bird-flu-usda-cattle.html">reported</a> that North Carolina officials confirmed there were asymptomatic cows in the state, which could also explain why the virus was detected in the commercial milk supply. It also suggests more herds may be infected than previously thought.</p></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1agbrixk lg8ac51 lg8ac50 xkp0cg1">On Wednesday, a month after the first confirmation, the USDA finally issued a <a href="https://www.aphis.usda.gov/sites/default/files/dairy-federal-order.pdf">federal order</a> requiring that laboratories and state veterinarians report farms with positive H5N1 tests and that lactating dairy cows must test negative for bird flu before crossing state lines (and <a href="https://www.statnews.com/2024/04/24/h5n1-bird-flu-usda-orders-dairy-cow-testing/">cooperate</a> with investigators). At a Wednesday press conference, the agency didn’t specify how the order will be enforced.</p></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><div id="why-regulation-and-response-go-hand-in-hand" class="_7ka5u1 _7ka5u0 duet--article--standard-heading xkp0cg1"><h2 class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup">Why regulation and response go hand-in-hand</h2></div></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1agbrixk lg8ac51 lg8ac50 xkp0cg1">The USDA’s sluggish response to a rapidly moving virus may leave some foreign observers scratching their heads. But much of it can be explained by an irresolvable conflict baked into its mission.</p></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1agbrixk lg8ac51 lg8ac50 xkp0cg1">The agency, <a href="https://newrepublic.com/article/164874/abolish-department-agriculture">according</a> to food industry scholars Gabriel Rosenberg and Jan Dutkiewicz, has “the oxymoronic double mandate of both promoting <em>and</em> regulating all of American agriculture—two disparate tasks that, when combined, effectively put the fox in charge of the henhouse.”</p></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1agbrixk lg8ac51 lg8ac50 xkp0cg1">More often than not, it’s heavy on the promotion and light on the regulation.</p></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1agbrixk lg8ac51 lg8ac50 xkp0cg1">The paradox has been at the center of its response to the bird flu’s decimation of the US poultry industry in recent years. While the USDA is developing several bird flu vaccines, it’s long been stubbornly opposed to a broad vaccination campaign due to <a href="/future-perfect/2022/11/22/23472207/bird-flu-vaccine-turkey-prices-chickens-hens-cull-depopulation">industry fears</a> that it’ll disrupt trade, a major source of revenue for US poultry companies, despite pleas from experts to give birds a bird flu shot. </p></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1agbrixk lg8ac51 lg8ac50 xkp0cg1">USDA has also been deferential to industry on matters of <a href="https://www.everand.com/podcast/598509314/Our-first-Climavores-guest-is-a-big-one-Secretary-of-Agriculture-Tom-Vilsack-Mike-and-Tamar-talk-climate-smart-commodities-with-the-Secretary">pollution</a>, <a href="https://www.agriculturedive.com/news/usda-extends-pilot-faster-pork-processing-lines-worker-safety/709609/">labor</a>, <a href="https://www.politico.com/news/2023/01/10/usda-meatpacker-bribery-case-00077093">political corruption</a>, <a href="/22838160/animal-welfare-labels-meat-dairy-eggs-humane-humanewashing">false advertising</a>, and <a href="/future-perfect/2022/12/11/23500157/neuralink-animal-testing-elon-musk-usda-probe">animal cruelty</a> across <a href="/future-perfect/23562811/puppy-mills-pets-dog-breeding-adoption-usda">numerous sectors</a>. And it’s not the only agency that too often takes a hands-off approach to problems stemming from food production. </p></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1agbrixk lg8ac51 lg8ac50 xkp0cg1">The FDA has failed to stringently regulate antibiotics used in animal farming, a pressing <a href="/future-perfect/2023/1/8/23542789/big-meat-antibiotics-resistance-fda">public health threat</a> that, in recent years, some European regulators have addressed in earnest. Agriculture is a top source of US <a href="https://www.cdc.gov/nceh/ehs/docs/understanding_cafos_nalboh.pdf">water</a> and <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2021/05/10/farm-pollution-deaths/">air</a> pollution, due in large part to congressional loopholes and weak enforcement on the part of the US Environmental Protection Agency.</p></div><div class="duet--article--article-body-component"><p class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup duet--article--standard-paragraph _1agbrixk lg8ac51 lg8ac50 xkp0cg1">It all adds up to what food industry experts call <a href="/future-perfect/2023/8/31/23852325/farming-myths-agricultural-exceptionalism-pollution-labor-animal-welfare-laws">“agricultural exceptionalism,”</a> in which the food industry operates under a different set of regulations than the rest of the <a href="/economy">economy</a>. The justification of such exceptionalism is that it’s necessary, given the importance of an abundant food supply. But that’s all the more reason not to give farmers and ranchers carte blanche to let disease circulate on American farms unchecked.</p></div><div class="duet--article--block-placement _80slsf1 _80slsf0 duet--article--article-body-component"><div><form class="mr4kua0 _1agbrix10 _1agbrixl mr4kua4"><div class="duet--cta--newsletter mr4kua7"><div class="mr4kuaa"><h2 class="mr4kuad">Future Perfect</h2><p class="mr4kuae"><span class="duet--article--dangerously-set-cms-markup">Explore the big, complicated problems the world faces and the most efficient ways to solve them. Sent twice a week.</span></p></div><div class="mr4kual mr4kuam"><fieldset><div class="mr4kuao"><div class="duet--cta--form-field-text bwzmda0 mr4kuar"><label for="email" class="_1vr06930 _142ra0g0">Email (required)</label><div class="bwzmda1"><input id="email" class="_1vr06931" aria-invalid="false" name="email" type="email" required="" placeholder="Enter your email"/></div></div><button class="duet--cta--button bl2rg41 bl2rg40 mr4kuav" type="submit"><span>Sign Up</span></button></div></fieldset><div class="mr4kuaz"><div class="mr4kuaf">By submitting your email, you agree to our<!-- --> <a href="https://www.voxmedia.com/legal/terms-of-use" class="mr4kuay">Terms</a> and <a href="https://www.voxmedia.com/legal/privacy-notice" class="mr4kuay">Privacy Notice</a>. <!-- -->This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google<!-- --> <a href="https://policies.google.com/privacy" class="mr4kuay">Privacy Policy</a> <!-- -->and<!-- --> <a href="https://policies.google.com/terms" class="mr4kuay">Terms of Service</a> <!-- -->apply.</div></div></div></div></form></div></div><aside class="_1tzd3in0 _1agbrix10"><p class="_1tzd3in1">You’ve read <!-- -->1<!-- --> article<!-- --> in the last month</p><div class="_1tzd3in2"><div class="_1tzd3in3"><p class="_1tzd3in4">Here at Vox, we're unwavering in our commitment to covering the issues that matter most to you — threats to democracy, immigration, reproductive rights, the environment, and the rising polarization across this country.</p><p class="_1tzd3in4">Our mission is to provide clear, accessible journalism that empowers you to stay informed and engaged in shaping our world. flu has had a busy couple of years. 
Since 2022, it’s ravaged the US poultry industry, as more than 90 million farmed birds — mostly egg-laying hens and turkeys — have either died from the virus or have been brutally killed in an attempt to stop the spread.
Last month, confirmation that the virus — a strain of highly pathogenic avian influenza known as H5N1 — had infected US dairy cows alarmed infectious disease experts, who worry that transmission to cows will allow the virus more opportunities to evolve. One dairy worker fell ill, increasing concerns about human risk levels. 
---
How did bird flu get so bad? Vox offers clarity.
We’ve been in the US’s worst bird flu outbreak since 2022. It continues to circulate on poultry farms, in wildlife, and now dairy farms. Here’s what you need to know:
* Yes, bird flu is a threat. It’s time to take it seriously.
* Bird flu jumped to cows, then to a human. Should we be worried?
* Can you get bird flu?
* Bird flu is surging again on poultry farms. The US is normalizing the cruelest mass killing method to stop it.
---
Now it’s in the milk supply. On Tuesday, the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) confirmed that genetic evidence of the virus had been found in commercially purchased milk. However, it’s unclear whether the milk contains live virus or mere fragments of the virus that were killed by pasteurization, a process that destroys harmful bacteria, but remain detectable. 
The FDA said it’ll soon release a nationwide survey of tested milk and that for now, the commercial milk supply remains safe, a claim that numerous independent experts have confirmed.
The news that the bird flu has been found in the US milk supply may raise alarm among some consumers, and the FDA has been criticized for prematurely assuring the safety of milk without hard data. But the real problem, which has received little attention, is the tepid and opaque response from the federal agency tasked with stopping the on-farm spread of the disease: the US Department of Agriculture (USDA).
What we know — and what we don’t — depends on the USDA 
Ever since the virus was detected on a Texas dairy farm in late March, infectious disease experts around the world have roundly criticized the USDA on multiple fronts. 
It took nearly a month for the agency to upload data containing genetic sequences of the virus, which scientists use to better understand its threat level. And once the sequence was uploaded, it was incomplete, lacking specifics that researchers say they needed to properly study the data.
“It’s as if the USDA is intentionally trying to hide data from the world,” Rick Bright, a former director of the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority at the US Department of Health and Human Services, told STAT. A Dutch virologist told STAT it should’ve taken the USDA days, not weeks, to share data and updates. 
Beyond the data obfuscation, there’s insufficient monitoring. The virus may have started circulating on US dairy farms months before it was detected, according to Michael Worobey, a biology professor at the University of Arizona. That suggests the need for better and more proactive pathogen monitoring on the part of the USDA.
And once H5N1 was confirmed in dairy cows, the USDA didn’t require dairy farms to conduct routine testing nor report positive H5N1 tests. The USDA has even tolerated uncooperative farmers, despite the high stakes of the disease spread.
“There has been a little bit of reluctance for some of the producers to allow us to gather information from their farms,” said Michael Watson, administrator of USDA’s Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, in a press conference on Wednesday. But, he added, “that has been improving.” 
This voluntary approach is a recurring theme in USDA policy; there’s even uncertainty as to whether the agency is enforcing orders for farmers to toss milk from infected cows to ensure it doesn’t wind up in the food supply, which could explain how traces of it were found in store-bought milk. 
Last week, the New York Times reported that North Carolina officials confirmed there were asymptomatic cows in the state, which could also explain why the virus was detected in the commercial milk supply. It also suggests more herds may be infected than previously thought.
On Wednesday, a month after the first confirmation, the USDA finally issued a federal order requiring that laboratories and state veterinarians report farms with positive H5N1 tests and that lactating dairy cows must test negative for bird flu before crossing state lines (and cooperate with investigators). At a Wednesday press conference, the agency didn’t specify how the order will be enforced.
Why regulation and response go hand-in-hand
The USDA’s sluggish response to a rapidly moving virus may leave some foreign observers scratching their heads. But much of it can be explained by an irresolvable conflict baked into its mission.
The agency, according to food industry scholars Gabriel Rosenberg and Jan Dutkiewicz, has “the oxymoronic double mandate of both promoting and regulating all of American agriculture—two disparate tasks that, when combined, effectively put the fox in charge of the henhouse.”
More often than not, it’s heavy on the promotion and light on the regulation.
The paradox has been at the center of its response to the bird flu’s decimation of the US poultry industry in recent years. While the USDA is developing several bird flu vaccines, it’s long been stubbornly opposed to a broad vaccination campaign due to industry fears that it’ll disrupt trade, a major source of revenue for US poultry companies, despite pleas from experts to give birds a bird flu shot. 
USDA has also been deferential to industry on matters of pollution, labor, political corruption, false advertising, and animal cruelty across numerous sectors. And it’s not the only agency that too often takes a hands-off approach to problems stemming from food production. 
The FDA has failed to stringently regulate antibiotics used in animal farming, a pressing public health threat that, in recent years, some European regulators have addressed in earnest. Agriculture is a top source of US water and air pollution, due in large part to congressional loopholes and weak enforcement on the part of the US Environmental Protection Agency.
It all adds up to what food industry experts call “agricultural exceptionalism,” in which the food industry operates under a different set of regulations than the rest of the economy. The justification of such exceptionalism is that it’s necessary, given the importance of an abundant food supply. But that’s all the more reason not to give farmers and ranchers carte blanche to let disease circulate on American farms unchecked.","excludedFromHomepage":false,"packages":{"nodes":[]},"ledeMediaData":{"__typename":"LedeMediaImageType","caption":{"html":"Dairy cows at an operation in Lodi, California, in 2020.","plaintext":"Dairy cows at an operation in Lodi, California, in 2020."},"credit":{"plaintext":"Jessica Christian/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images","html":"Jessica Christian/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images"},"hideCredit":false,"image":{"thumbnails":{"horizontal":{"url":"https://platform.vox.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/25417440/GettyImages_1218481600.jpg?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0,0,100,100"},"square":{"url":"https://platform.vox.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/25417440/GettyImages_1218481600.jpg?quality=90&strip=all&crop=16.666666666667,0,66.666666666667,100"},"vertical":{"url":"https://platform.vox.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/25417440/GettyImages_1218481600.jpg?quality=90&strip=all&crop=23.333333333333,0,53.333333333333,100"}},"title":"Black and white spotted dairy cows with numbered orange ear tags lean their heads out of barred stalls.","credit":{"plaintext":"Jessica Christian/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images","html":"Jessica Christian/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images"},"id":"dngyOmltYWdlOjM5MDQ="}}}},"errors":[]},{"operationName":"ArticleCategoryRecircContainerQuery","variables":{"categoryNodeId":"dngyOmNhdGVnb3J5Ojk0MA==","excludeLatest":0},"data":{"node":{"__typename":"CategoryResourceType","title":"Future Perfect","path":"/future-perfect","recirc":{"nodes":[{"__typename":"PostResourceType","__isFeedContentResourceInterface":"PostResourceType","id":"dngyOnBvc3Q6Mzk3Mjgy","wpId":397282,"chorusId":null,"chorusUuid":null,"resourceType":"post","dek":{"html":"I feel intense guilt after getting angry. readabilityObject.title: Bird flu in milk is alarming — but not for the reason you think
readabilityObject.content:
Bird flu has had a busy couple of years.

Since 2022, it’s ravaged the US poultry industry, as more than 90 million farmed birds — mostly egg-laying hens and turkeys — have either died from the virus or have been brutally killed in an attempt to stop the spread.

Last month, confirmation that the virus — a strain of highly pathogenic avian influenza known as H5N1 — had infected US dairy cows alarmed infectious disease experts, who worry that transmission to cows will allow the virus more opportunities to evolve. One dairy worker fell ill, increasing concerns about human risk levels.

How did bird flu get so bad? Vox offers clarity.

We’ve been in the US’s worst bird flu outbreak since 2022. It continues to circulate on poultry farms, in wildlife, and now dairy farms. Here’s what you need to know:

Now it’s in the milk supply. On Tuesday, the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) confirmed that genetic evidence of the virus had been found in commercially purchased milk. However, it’s unclear whether the milk contains live virus or mere fragments of the virus that were killed by pasteurization, a process that destroys harmful bacteria, but remain detectable.

The FDA said it’ll soon release a nationwide survey of tested milk and that for now, the commercial milk supply remains safe, a claim that numerous independent experts have confirmed.

The news that the bird flu has been found in the US milk supply may raise alarm among some consumers, and the FDA has been criticized for prematurely assuring the safety of milk without hard data. But the real problem, which has received little attention, is the tepid and opaque response from the federal agency tasked with stopping the on-farm spread of the disease: the US Department of Agriculture (USDA).

What we know — and what we don’t — depends on the USDA

Ever since the virus was detected on a Texas dairy farm in late March, infectious disease experts around the world have roundly criticized the USDA on multiple fronts.

It took nearly a month for the agency to upload data containing genetic sequences of the virus, which scientists use to better understand its threat level. And once the sequence was uploaded, it was incomplete, lacking specifics that researchers say they needed to properly study the data.

“It’s as if the USDA is intentionally trying to hide data from the world,” Rick Bright, a former director of the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority at the US Department of Health and Human Services, told STAT. A Dutch virologist told STAT it should’ve taken the USDA days, not weeks, to share data and updates.

Beyond the data obfuscation, there’s insufficient monitoring. The virus may have started circulating on US dairy farms months before it was detected, according to Michael Worobey, a biology professor at the University of Arizona. That suggests the need for better and more proactive pathogen monitoring on the part of the USDA.

And once H5N1 was confirmed in dairy cows, the USDA didn’t require dairy farms to conduct routine testing nor report positive H5N1 tests. The USDA has even tolerated uncooperative farmers, despite the high stakes of the disease spread.

“There has been a little bit of reluctance for some of the producers to allow us to gather information from their farms,” said Michael Watson, administrator of USDA’s Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, in a press conference on Wednesday. But, he added, “that has been improving.”

This voluntary approach is a recurring theme in USDA policy; there’s even uncertainty as to whether the agency is enforcing orders for farmers to toss milk from infected cows to ensure it doesn’t wind up in the food supply, which could explain how traces of it were found in store-bought milk.

Last week, the New York Times reported that North Carolina officials confirmed there were asymptomatic cows in the state, which could also explain why the virus was detected in the commercial milk supply. It also suggests more herds may be infected than previously thought.

On Wednesday, a month after the first confirmation, the USDA finally issued a federal order requiring that laboratories and state veterinarians report farms with positive H5N1 tests and that lactating dairy cows must test negative for bird flu before crossing state lines (and cooperate with investigators). At a Wednesday press conference, the agency didn’t specify how the order will be enforced.

Why regulation and response go hand-in-hand

The USDA’s sluggish response to a rapidly moving virus may leave some foreign observers scratching their heads. But much of it can be explained by an irresolvable conflict baked into its mission.

The agency, according to food industry scholars Gabriel Rosenberg and Jan Dutkiewicz, has “the oxymoronic double mandate of both promoting and regulating all of American agriculture—two disparate tasks that, when combined, effectively put the fox in charge of the henhouse.”

More often than not, it’s heavy on the promotion and light on the regulation.

The paradox has been at the center of its response to the bird flu’s decimation of the US poultry industry in recent years. While the USDA is developing several bird flu vaccines, it’s long been stubbornly opposed to a broad vaccination campaign due to industry fears that it’ll disrupt trade, a major source of revenue for US poultry companies, despite pleas from experts to give birds a bird flu shot.

USDA has also been deferential to industry on matters of pollution, labor, political corruption, false advertising, and animal cruelty across numerous sectors. And it’s not the only agency that too often takes a hands-off approach to problems stemming from food production.

The FDA has failed to stringently regulate antibiotics used in animal farming, a pressing public health threat that, in recent years, some European regulators have addressed in earnest. Agriculture is a top source of US water and air pollution, due in large part to congressional loopholes and weak enforcement on the part of the US Environmental Protection Agency.

It all adds up to what food industry experts call “agricultural exceptionalism,” in which the food industry operates under a different set of regulations than the rest of the economy. The justification of such exceptionalism is that it’s necessary, given the importance of an abundant food supply. But that’s all the more reason not to give farmers and ranchers carte blanche to let disease circulate on American farms unchecked.

Future Perfect

Explore the big, complicated problems the world faces and the most efficient ways to solve them. Sent twice a week.

But the real problem, which has received little attention, is the tepid and opaque response from the federal agency tasked with stopping the on-farm spread of the disease: the US Department of Agriculture (USDA).What we know — and what we don’t — depends on the USDA Ever since the virus was detected on a Texas dairy farm in late March, infectious disease experts around the world have roundly criticized the USDA on multiple fronts. It took nearly a month for the agency to upload data containing genetic sequences of the virus, which scientists use to better understand its threat level. And once the sequence was uploaded, it was incomplete, lacking specifics that researchers say they needed to properly study the data.“It’s as if the USDA is intentionally trying to hide data from the world,” Rick Bright, a former director of the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority at the US Department of Health and Human Services, told STAT. A Dutch virologist told STAT it should’ve taken the USDA days, not weeks, to share data and updates. Beyond the data obfuscation, there’s insufficient monitoring. The virus may have started circulating on US dairy farms months before it was detected, according to Michael Worobey, a biology professor at the University of Arizona. That suggests the need for better and more proactive pathogen monitoring on the part of the USDA.And once H5N1 was confirmed in dairy cows, the USDA didn’t require dairy farms to conduct routine testing nor report positive H5N1 tests. The USDA has even tolerated uncooperative farmers, despite the high stakes of the disease spread.“There has been a little bit of reluctance for some of the producers to allow us to gather information from their farms,” said Michael Watson, administrator of USDA’s Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, in a press conference on Wednesday. But, he added, “that has been improving.” This voluntary approach is a recurring theme in USDA policy; there’s even uncertainty as to whether the agency is enforcing orders for farmers to toss milk from infected cows to ensure it doesn’t wind up in the food supply, which could explain how traces of it were found in store-bought milk. Last week, the New York Times reported that North Carolina officials confirmed there were asymptomatic cows in the state, which could also explain why the virus was detected in the commercial milk supply. It also suggests more herds may be infected than previously thought.On Wednesday, a month after the first confirmation, the USDA finally issued a federal order requiring that laboratories and state veterinarians report farms with positive H5N1 tests and that lactating dairy cows must test negative for bird flu before crossing state lines (and cooperate with investigators). At a Wednesday press conference, the agency didn’t specify how the order will be enforced.Why regulation and response go hand-in-handThe USDA’s sluggish response to a rapidly moving virus may leave some foreign observers scratching their heads. But much of it can be explained by an irresolvable conflict baked into its mission.The agency, according to food industry scholars Gabriel Rosenberg and Jan Dutkiewicz, has “the oxymoronic double mandate of both promoting and regulating all of American agriculture—two disparate tasks that, when combined, effectively put the fox in charge of the henhouse.”More often than not, it’s heavy on the promotion and light on the regulation.The paradox has been at the center of its response to the bird flu’s decimation of the US poultry industry in recent years. While the USDA is developing several bird flu vaccines, it’s long been stubbornly opposed to a broad vaccination campaign due to industry fears that it’ll disrupt trade, a major source of revenue for US poultry companies, despite pleas from experts to give birds a bird flu shot. USDA has also been deferential to industry on matters of pollution, labor, political corruption, false advertising, and animal cruelty across numerous sectors. And it’s not the only agency that too often takes a hands-off approach to problems stemming from food production. The FDA has failed to stringently regulate antibiotics used in animal farming, a pressing public health threat that, in recent years, some European regulators have addressed in earnest. Agriculture is a top source of US water and air pollution, due in large part to congressional loopholes and weak enforcement on the part of the US Environmental Protection Agency.It all adds up to what food industry experts call “agricultural exceptionalism,” in which the food industry operates under a different set of regulations than the rest of the economy. The justification of such exceptionalism is that it’s necessary, given the importance of an abundant food supply. But that’s all the more reason not to give farmers and ranchers carte blanche to let disease circulate on American farms unchecked.Future PerfectExplore the big, complicated problems the world faces and the most efficient ways to solve them. Sent twice a week.
